MachineLearning.functions.column_ratio(X)[source]

Return the ratio of the 2 series of a DataFrame.

Parameters:

X (pd.DataFrame) – The dataframe containing the two series to calculate the ratio of.

Returns:

The ratio of the two series in the dataframe.

Return type:

np.ndarray

MachineLearning.functions.cross_val_accuracy(model, X, y, cv=3)[source]

Compute the cross-validation accuracy for a given model and dataset.

Parameters:

  • model (sklearn.linear_model.SGDClassifier) – Any model from sklearn that implements the scikit-learn estimator interface.

  • X (Union[numpy.ndarray, pandas.DataFrame]) – The feature matrix.

  • y (Union[numpy.ndarray, pandas.Series]) – The target vector (labels).

  • cv (int) – The number of folds in the cross-validation. Defaults to 3.

Returns:

The measured accuracy on each fold.

Return type:

np.ndarray

MachineLearning.functions.display_cv_results(search)[source]

This function displays the results of CV search as a nice pandas.DataFrame.

Parameters:

search (sklearn.model_selection.GridSearchCV) – The GridSearchCV object.

MachineLearning.functions.display_feature_importances(search, df_columns=None)[source]

Display the importances of each feature for a CV search exploration.

Parameters:

  • search (sklearn.model_selection.GridSearchCV) – The GridSearchCV object.

  • df_columns (list) – The list of all features. Defaults to None.

MachineLearning.functions.eval_model(model, X, y, cv=10)[source]

This function prints the training error and the validation errors. If the training error is much smaller than the validation errors, it means that the model is overfitting the data.

Parameters:

  • model (sklearn.base.BaseEstimator) – The model to evaluate.

  • X (Union[numpy.ndarray, pandas.DataFrame]) – The feature matrix.

  • y (Union[numpy.ndarray, pandas.Series]) – The target vector (labels).

  • cv (int) – The number of cross-validation subsets (folds). Defaults to 10.

MachineLearning.functions.load_housing_data() → DataFrame[source]

Load the California housing dataset from a local file or from a remote URL.

Returns:

A pandas DataFrame containing the California housing dataset.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

Raises:

urllib.error.URLError – If the download of the dataset fails.

MachineLearning.functions.load_mnist(name='mnist_784', path='../datasets', as_frame=False, force_reload=False) → Union[Memory, dict][source]

Load the MNIST dataset from a local file or from the OpenML repository.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – The name of the MNIST dataset to load. Defaults to ‘mnist_784’.

  • path (str) – The path where to cache the dataset. Defaults to ‘Datasets’.

  • as_frame (bool) – Whether to return the data as a pandas DataFrame. Defaults to False.

  • force_reload (bool) – Whether to force a reload of the dataset from the OpenML repository. Defaults to False.

Returns:

A dictionary or a memory cache object containing the MNIST dataset.

Return type:

Union[joblib.Memory, dict]

Raises:

ValueError – If an invalid value is provided for the as_frame parameter.

MachineLearning.functions.plot_digit(image_data, show=True)[source]

Plot as an image the digit from MNIST dataset.

Parameters:

  • image_data (np.ndarray) – The digit data.

  • show (bool) – If true, display the figure. Defaults to True.

MachineLearning.functions.plot_preci_recall_tradeoff(precisions, recalls, thresholds, threshold=3000, figname='precision_recall_vs_threshold_plot', last_curve=True)[source]

Plot the precision and the recall curves on the same figure, and show their values for a given threshold.

Parameters:

  • precisions (np.ndarray) – The precisions.

  • recalls (np.ndarray) – The recalls.

  • thresholds (np.ndarray) – The thresholds.

  • threshold (int) – The threshold to display on the figure. Defaults to 3000.

  • figname (str) – The name of the figure to save. Defaults to “precision_recall_vs_threshold_plot”.

  • last_curve (bool) – If False, only plot the precision and recall curves. In order to add more curves to the plot. Defaults to True.

MachineLearning.functions.plot_preci_vs_recall(precisions, recalls, thresholds, threshold=3000, figname='precision_vs_recall_plot', last_curve=True)[source]

Plot the precision as a function of the recall.

Parameters:

  • precisions (np.ndarray) – The precisions.

  • recalls (np.ndarray) – The recalls.

  • thresholds (np.ndarray) – The thresholds.

  • threshold (int) – The threshold to display on the figure. Defaults to 3000.

  • figname (str) – The name of the figure to save. Defaults to “precision_recall_vs_threshold_plot”.

  • last_curve (bool) – If False, only plot the precision and recall curves. In order to add more curves to the plot. Defaults to True.

MachineLearning.functions.plot_roc_curve(fpr, tpr, thresholds, threshold=3000, last_curve=True)[source]

Plot the ROC curve

Parameters:

  • fpr (np.ndarray) – The false positive rates.

  • tpr (np.ndarray) – The truth positive rates.

  • thresholds (np.ndarray) – The thresholds

  • threshold (int) – The particular threshold to display. Defaults to 3000.

  • last_curve (bool) – If False, only plot the ROC curve. In order to add more curves to the plot. Defaults to True.

MachineLearning.functions.ratio_name(function_transformer, feature_names_in)[source]

Function needed in ratio_pipeline() to be able to use get_feature_names_out().

Parameters:

  • function_transformer (sklearn.preprocessing.FunctionTransformer) – A transformer that implements a function.

  • feature_names_in (list) – The input features.

Returns:

A list of feature names out.

Return type:

list

MachineLearning.functions.read_and_split_data(filename, random_state=42) → Tuple[DataFrame, DataFrame][source]

Read dataset from a CSV file and split into train and test sets using stratified suffled split.

Parameters:

  • filename – The name of the CSV file to load.

  • random_state (int) – The seed of the random generator used to shuffle the data. Defaults to 42.

Returns:

The train and test datasets.

Return type:

Tuple[pd.DataFrame, pd.DataFrame]

MachineLearning.functions.save_fig(fig_id, images_path='images', tight_layout=True, fig_extension='png', resolution=300)[source]

Save the pyplot figure

Parameters:

  • fig_id (str) – The name of the figure.

  • images_path (str) – The path to the directory in which the figure is saved. Defaults to “Images”.

  • tight_layout (bool) – Enable tight_layout for the figure. Defaults to True.

  • fig_extension (str) – The extension of the file that stores the figure. Defaults to “png”.

  • resolution (int) – The resolution of the figure. Defaults to 300.

MachineLearning.functions.shift_image(image, dx, dy, size=(28, 28))[source]

Shifts an image by a specified number of pixels in the x and y directions.

Parameters:

  • image (numpy.ndarray) – The image to shift.

  • dx (float) – The number of pixels to shift the image in the x direction.

  • dy (float) – The number of pixels to shift the image in the y direction.

  • size (tuple) – The dimensions of the image to be reshaped before shifting. Defaults to (28, 28).

Returns:

The shifted image.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

MachineLearning.functions.shuffle_and_split_data(data, test_ratio, random_state=42)[source]

Shuffle data and split it into a train and a test sets.

Parameters:

  • data (Union[np.ndarray, pd.DataFrame]) – The dataset to shuffle and split.

  • test_ratio (float) – The ratio of test data over all data. Range from 0 to 1. Usually chosen around 0.2.

  • random_state (int) – the seed of the random generator used to shuffle the data. Defaults to 42.

Returns:

The train and test datasets.

Return type:

Tuple[pd.DataFrame, pd.DataFrame]

MachineLearning.functions.split_data_with_id_hash(data, test_ratio, id_column)[source]

Split dataset using the IDs from a column of the DataFrame.

Parameters:

  • data (pd.DataFrame) – The dataset to splot

  • test_ratio (float) – The ratio of test data over all data. Range from 0 to 1. Usually chosen around 0.2.

  • id_column (str) – The name of the column to use as IDs.

Returns:

The train and test datasets.

Return type:

Tuple[pd.DataFrame, pd.DataFrame]
